titlestmt.titleproper: A Finding Aid to the San Francisco Women Artists Records, 1925-1999, in the Archives of American Art AAA.sanfrawa
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Anna Rimel
titlestmt.sponsor: Funding for the processing of this collection was provided by the Smithsonian Institution Collections Care and Preservation Fund.

note.p: This finding aid is associated with a MARC collection-level record 216572.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2015-09-28T15:23-0400

did.abstract: The San Francisco Women Artists records measure 15.3 linear feet, date from 1925 to 1999, and include administrative records, correspondence, membership files, exhibition files, inventory records, printed material, twenty scrapbooks, photographs, and eight photograph albums.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: The collection was minimally processed and a finding aid prepared by Anna Rimel in 2015 with funding provided by the Smithsonian Institution’s Collections Care and Preservation Fund. The Archives of American Art has implemented accelerated processing tactics when possible to provide access to more of our collections. For this collection, accelerated processing included arrangement to the series, subseries and folder levels, adhering to the creator’s original arrangement as much as possible. Generally, folder contents were simply verified with the original folder titles, but items within folders were not arranged further. All materials were rehoused in archival folders and boxes for long-term stability, but staples and other fasteners have not all been removed.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged as 8 series:

list.item: Series 1: Administrative Records, 1925-circa 1998 (6.3 linear feet; Boxes 1-6, 15)
Series 3: Membership Files, 1925-circa 1998 (1.5 linear feet; Boxes 7-8)
Series 4: Exhibition Files, 1947-circa 1998 (0.7 linear feet; Boxes 8-9)
Series 5: Inventory Records, circa 1974-circa 1985 (0.4 linear feet; Boxes 9-10)
Series 6: Printed Material, 1926-1999 (1.5 linear feet; Boxes 10-11, 16)

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Use of original papers requires an appointment and is limited to the Archives’ Washington, D.C. Research Center. Contact Reference Services for more information. Use of archival audiovisual recordings with no duplicate access copy requires advance notice.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: The San Francisco Women Artists records are owned by the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution. Literary rights as possessed by the donor have been dedicated to public use for research, study, and scholarship. The collection is subject to all copyright laws.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: San Francisco Women Artists (SFWA) is one of California's oldest arts organizations, dating its founding to 1887 as the Sketch Club. At that time, members met monthly to share and critique one another's work and to travel together on sketching trips. After the great earthquake in 1906 destroyed the club's headquarters, the group floundered and reorganized and merged with other organizations that also included men. By 1925, however, a core group of women broke away and formed the San Francisco Society of Women Artists. The SFWA's founding mission was "... the study and furtherance of all interests common to the arts both graphic and plastic … and to support causes neglected by other art organizations in the Bay Area.” Early members include Alice B. Chittenden, Helen Hyde, Matilda Lotz, Clara Taggart McChesney, M. Evelyn McCormick, Dora Williams, and Eva Almond Withrow. Other members included Marcelle Labaudt, Dorr Bothwell, Claire Falkenstein, Ruth Asawa, Nell Sinton, Imogen Cunningham, Eleanor Dickenson, Jo Hansen, Emmy Lou Packard, Eleanore Rappe, Ruth Armer, Barbara Spring, Beth Van Hoesen and Dorothy Winslade.

The Society held its first exhibition in 1926. In 1932, Frida Kahlo’s painting, Frieda and Diego Rivera, was shown at the “Sixth Annual Exhibition of the San Francisco Society of Women Artists” and was the first public showing of Kahlo’s work. In 1946 the organization shortened its name to the San Francisco Women Artists.

In 1976 the SFWA and exective director Marcelle Labaudt were commended in a Senate Resolution for “outstanding contributions to the cultural enhancement of the City of San Francisco.” In 1983 the SFWA procured a gallery at 451 Hayes Street, which provided exhibition space for members, as well as an art rental program. In 1985 the gallery moved to 370 Hayes Street. The SFWA celebrated its centennial in 1994 with an exhibition including work of many past members.
This organization continues to host monthly themed juried shows and is dedicated to encouraging and promoting the work of women artists.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The San Francisco Women Artists records measure 15.3 linear feet and date from 1925 to 1999. The activities of the SFWA are documented through administrative records, correspondence, membership files, exhibition files, inventory records, printed material, twenty scrapbooks, photographs, and eight photograph albums.

Administrative records include daily journals and publicity materials, historical materials and founding documents, meeting minutes and agendas, artist council and committee meetings, and member and patron surveys. Also found within administrative records are materials on Marcelle Labaudt, SFWA Executive Secretary then Executive Director for many years, including original film footage and sound recordings for a career retrospective film project. Correspondence is with potential donors and patrons, board members, members, and artists. Membership files contain ledgers of paid memberships, lists of dropped members, membership applications and rosters, membership biographies, renewals and statistics, and membership directories.

Exhibition files contain price lists and display placards, slides and photographs, and printed materials relating to shows and exhibitions presented by various SFWA members and cooperating organizations, including the San Francisco Art Institute. Shows include “Celebration of International Women” (1991), “The Paintings of Dorothy Windslade” (1994), annual juried SFWA shows and emerging artists exhibitions (1947-circa 1994), “Art of Susan A. Whitney Exhibit and Silent Auction” (1997), and “Hands and Heart, the Art of Healing” (1997), among others.

Inventory records contain artist inventory cards noting various artwork and exhibitions. Printed material includes books, SFWA bulletins, SFWA calendars, clippings, and exhibition printed materials, such as announcements, brochures, and catalogs. Twenty scrapbooks document the SFWA through clippings, exhibition documentation, photographs, biographies, and annotations. Eight photograph albums depict exhibitions and shows, artwork and artists. Also found within photographs are slides, negatives, and loose photographs depicting works of art, gallery and receptions, and meetings.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Pam Foley, president of the San Francisco Women Artists donated the records in 1999.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Administrative records include a wide variety of materials documenting the organization's general administrative, financial, and operating affairs; founding and history; events; board, council, and committee activities;and membership information. Also found are biographical materials on Marcelle Labaudt, long-time member and and executive director of the SFWA. Within the files concerning Labault is material documenting a film project about Labault by Marlana Beckman, which includes film and sound recordings.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is arranged by functions, activities, and subjects.

did.unittitle: Events, San Francisco Annual Arts Festival
Events, SFWA and KQED Channel 9 Pledge Night
Financial Files, Income and Expense Reports
Financial Files, Marketing and Budget Plans
Founding Documents, Constitution, By-Laws, and Articles of Incorporation
Bell, Curtis and Snider Fine Art Planning Proposal
Dorr Bothwell Lecture, "SF Art Institute Lecture"

physdesc.extent: Includes paper notes and additional description.

did.unittitle: Radio Program, "KPFA-FM Heritage Program" Sound Recording
Video Recording, "Art and Music: Everybody's Angels"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Oversized film material located in Box 15.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Cassette tapes may be copies of sound reels.

did.unittitle: Slides, Carousel I: "Attic Reception, Labaudt Slides and Festivals"
Slides, Carousel II: "Lucien Labaudt's Reception Anniversary"
Oversized "Marcelle Labaudt Film" Materials, Film Recordings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence is with donors and patrons, artists and members, board members, SFWA President Stefanie Steinberg, and others. Additional correspondence is found in Series 1.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Membership files include rosters, renewals, directories, statistics, and applications, dropped members lists, printed membership applications, a letter for overdue membership, as well as two ledgers of paid memberships.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Exhibition files are incomplete and contain announcements, photographs and slides, catalogs, notes and correspondence. Files are found for "The Paintings of Dorothy Winslade" (1994), "Hands and Heart, the Art of Healing" (1997), "Annual SFWA Emerging Artists Show" (1988-1994), and "International Women" (1997), among many others. Also found are exhibition lists, price lists, and placards.

did.unittitle: Annual San Francisco Women Artists, Jurors and Jury Ballots (circa 1947-1966)
"Art of Susan A. Whitney, Exhibit and Silent Auction" (1997)
"Hands and Heart, the Art of Healing" (1997)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains artist inventory cards noting artists, some artwork, and some exhibitions.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Inventory records are arranged in general alphabetical order and grouped to maintain the order in which they were found.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Printed materials include calendars, clippings, exhibition announcements, brochures and catalogs, general exhibition materials, general printed materials, and two books.

did.unittitle: Book, The Development of Modern Art in Northern California: Part I
Book, The Development of Modern Art in Northern California: Part II
Oversized Calendars, San Francisco Women Artists

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Twenty scrapbooks (bound and unbound) contain clippings and exhibition materials, such as announcements, photographs, some notes, and biographies.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Scrapbooks are arranged in chronological order.

did.unittitle: Scrapbook 13, "Biographies, 100 Years of Women in the Arts"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Eight bound and unbound photograph albums, photographs, negatives, and slides depict artwork, exhibitions, galleries, events, artists at work, and images for an exhibition catalog.
